title: Synthetic Recap
body:
VANCOUVER, B.C. (AP) — In a dimly lit arena destined for obscurity, one man authored a performance destined for the record books. Mitch Richmond didn't just beat the Vancouver Grizzlies; he put on a breathtaking, one-man show, carrying the Sacramento Kings to a 109-101 victory with a career-high 47 points.

From the opening tip, Richmond was a man possessed. He was a flurry of motion, slicing through the Vancouver defense and rising for jumpers with a defender perpetually in his face. There was no answer for him. The Grizzlies, in just their second season, could only watch as the All-Star guard meticulously dismantled them. He was the relentless force, the constant hum of offense in a game that often lacked other consistent rhythms.

While the Kings got secondary contributions from Olden Polynice (12 points) and Corliss Williamson (10 points), this night belonged solely to Richmond. His 47-point eruption wasn't just scoring; it was an act of sheer will. Every time Vancouver threatened to close the gap, there was Richmond, answering with a cold-blooded three or a powerful drive to the hoop. He was the firewall against any hope of a Grizzlies comeback.

Shareef Abdur-Rahim fought valiantly for Vancouver, leading his team with 24 points, but his effort was a footnote in the face of Richmond’s historic night. The Grizzlies’ balanced attack was simply no match for one man’s singular brilliance.

The final buzzer sounded on a Kings victory, but the score was a mere subplot. The real story was the number 47, a career-high etched into the ledger, a testament to a night when Mitch Richmond was, quite simply, unstoppable. He didn't just win a game; he created a memory.
